history.content:
As long as you have all the prereqs, take 140! (not sure if she enforces the prereqs so check that). 

Stat140 doesn't require any previous courses on probability (besides basic addition/multiplication rule), and it builds every topic from the ground up. Since the topics are covered over the course of a entire semester, instead of the rushed 6 weeks of cs70, the content is much more digestible (also if you took Data100, they spend a super rushed lecture on probability topics like expectation, variance etc and don't do the topic justice so again the content will be more digestible than in that course). 

Additionally, I am of the strong (and biased) opinion that nobody can teach probability better than Professor Adhikari, and I believe that if you didn't like probability in the past, she just might change your mind. 

In terms of your ability to survive, since you've already taken 70, you have at least seen the topics before (even if you didn't fully understand them). Now, you can take the time to really understand the nuances of the topics you missed in 70. Since you are willing to put in the work, and have a strong desire to learn this material that you've never had a chance to love, you can succeed. At some point in courses, its less about preparation and more about willpower in order to succeed (coming from someone who entered Stat140 with only Math 1b under my belt - I don't recommend that lol but its still possible to do well). 

Even if you don't plan to do ML/AI in the future, I still think based on your CS background you can get more out of 140 than 134. Its the modern age of computing, and Adhikari herself said that 134 is the probability she learned in college decades ago. When I took the course, I really appreciated how it tied more mathematical topics of probability to modern CS applications. In my semester, we had a lab that showed we can decrypt an encrypted piece of text with Markov chains! While obviously that's not the most efficient way to do it, I just thought it was the coolest application I've ever seen. 

I cannot speak to the grade average since it's been a while since I've taken it. 

Lastly, I've found that there will always be those brillaint CS/EECS/STAT/DS majors in pretty much any class you take at Berkeley , so at some point you have to learn to not let that bother you and do your own thing ;)

tl;dr: It's worth it, take 140

children.subject: +1 This! Adhikari is also an awesome professor! She's always willing to put in time for the students and walk you through the steps :) the TAs pour a lot of time and passion into the class too, it's a great vibe.

Stat 140 was my favorite class so far. I took it before 70, and all the probability was taught ground up. It's just such a well made course. I never learned so much in one semester. Yea it takes time, but not more than 15 hours of week (in my opinion), especially if you've seen probability before in 70 and 188.

Having the coding lab component really deepened my understanding of the probability more than anything else could.

It's honestly such a wonderful course. Take it!

I am biased though - I loved the course so much I went on to tutor it for a semester, nnd math is not something I struggle too much with. Even with that, I would still recommend Stat 140 for you.
Does anyone know if Adhikari will be teaching Stat 140 next semester? It's currently listed as "staff" of the schedule.

When I took it, Prof. Adhikari did reference Data 8 material every so often, but it felt more as a supplement than core content (to be honest I didn't really remember a number of the examples she brought up so). Workload for homework is similar to 170 depending on how well you click with 170 vs 140.

When I took it spring 2017 she enforced the prereqs so something to check. 

The website also lists Stat20 or Data100 as ok prereqs as well.

So I didn't take Data 8 yet and I kinda want to take 140 for the same reasons as op. Would this be an issue? I'm not sure if it's a hard prereq but I've taken 70, and taking 170 currently. I'm also thinking of taking 162 and C106A so curious about this workload

I believe labs were removed this semester, and replaced with a second discussion (I think?) as they were trying out a new structure. Not sure if they'll revert next semester or keep it like this semester but it seems like they'll be keeping the double discussion/no lab structure for next semester if it's not listed on the schedule?

I only see the one discussion per week on there, so without an instructor, any classroom assignments for discussion, or a lab, I hope it gets fixed soon.  No classroom info for STAT C100 either.  I tried contacting a STAT advisor but got no reply back.
Also, there’s no lab sections listed on the schedule.  Did that get eliminated or is the schedule for 140 just very incomplete?
Is Stat 140 doable with 162 and 160 (along with full-time recruiting) if I'm similar to OP who isn't good at probability?

history.content:
TLDR: Is stat 140 the right choice for me if I did bad on CS 70(especially probability part), not sure about my mathematical maturity, not willing to put more than 10-15 hours of work for this class, but passionate to learn what I couldn't in CS 70, and eager to learn about the topics listed on syllabus. 

I'm thinking about taking stat 140 next semester but I'm anxious about it after reading about peoples' experiences with the class and the grade breakdown.

First, some background: I have taken all lower div cs classes, 188, 170, 100, 169 and 186. I disliked the probability the most. I want to give it another chance because I feel like its really useful, interesting and CS70 did not do an amazing job teaching it when I was taking it. 

Problems: If I have struggled a lot during probability part of 70 and even 188, can I actually survive stat 140? Close to everyone online agree that this class requires a lot of effort and its' pretty hard. I know that Prof Adhikari and the TAs are amazing(I have taken some classes with them), also most of the people taking this class are brilliant CS/EECS/STAT/CS/DS majors with a decent amount of mathematical maturity. So I wonder, why it has a much lower grade average than notoriously hard cs classes like 170, 189, EE 126, etc.? I also plan to work on something that does not do ML/AI in the future, so is a probability course still useful for someone who wants to focus on software engineering?

Is Stat 134 or another probability course a better option for me?
history.subject: Taking Stat 140 or not?
